basicgraphics

Class BasicFrame

  • java.lang.Object
    • basicgraphics.BasicFrame

  • public class BasicFrame
extends java.lang.Object
    Manages a JFrame object for you, hopefully making it easier to get the gui layout you want for your application. You can find examples of how this package can be used in @see basicgraphics.examples.BasicGraphics, in @see basicflyer.Flyer, and @see basicshooter.Game.

      Fields

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BasicFrame(java.lang.String title)
      The title will be displayed on the top of the main frame.

    • Method Detail

      • getFrame

        public static javax.swing.JFrame getFrame()

      • add

        public void add(java.lang.String[][] layout,
                java.lang.String loc,
                javax.swing.JComponent jc)
        Enables you to design your screen with a 2D ascii array. The design takes the form of a rectangular grid in which logically rectangular regions on the screen are mapped to display components. Java determines the size of the individual cells in the grid, based on the name.
        Parameters:
        layout - - A 2-D array describing the layout
        loc - - One of the names in the layout.
        jc - - The component that should be placed at location loc.

      • setAllFonts

        public void setAllFonts(java.awt.Font f)
        Set the font on all components. This should be called prior to making the gui visible.
        Parameters:
        f -

      • add

        public void add(java.lang.String name,
                java.awt.Component c,
                int x,
                int y,
                int xw,
                int yw)
        Each "name" should uniquely identify a display element. Apart from that, it can be anything. Each "c" identifies a JButton, JLabel, SpriteComponent, etc. to be added to the display area. The values x, y, xw, yw provide logical coordinates and sizes for the display item. Thus, this example: 
           add("j1",new JLabel("j1"),0,0,1,1);
   add("j2",new JLabel("j2"),1,0,1,1);
   add("j3",new JLabel("j3"),0,1,2,1);
        creates three JLabels. The first two are on the top row, and the third is on the second, but the third is the same width as the top two put together (because the widths add to the same value).
        Parameters:
        name -
        c -
        x -
        y -
        xw -
        yw -

      • show

        public void show()
        Make the frame visible. Until this method is called, sizes of various components will be unknown. At this time the display will be checked for parts of the gui which have not been filled in. Red boxes with an X will be placed in each.

      • repaint

        public void repaint(java.lang.String name)
        Call this method to request repainting of the named component. The name is the one supplied when the component was added.

      • createImage

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage createImage(int w,
                                                       int h)
        A utility to create images. Once you have an image, you can call the getGraphics() method in order to draw on it.
        Parameters:
        w -
        h -
        Returns:

      • getContentPane

        public java.awt.Container getContentPane()

      • addKeyListener

        public void addKeyListener(java.awt.event.KeyListener kl)
        Usually you subclass a KeyAdapter to handle keyboard events. It should make things simpler for you if you give your KeyAdapters to the BasicFrame rather than trying to give it to a component.
        Parameters:
        kl -

        public void dispose()
        Make it go away.
